section.title: Introduction
section.para: In this tutorial, we will create and save a simple card, load QSOs from an ADIF file and select the QSOs to print, and finally, print the QSOs.
The first steps are to become familiar with the HamQSLer splash screen , become familiar with the main program window, and then set a few user preferences.

section.title: The HamQSLer Splash Screen
section.para: When HamQSLer starts, it performs a number of functions:

listitem.para: Performs a number of initialization steps including initializing the HamQSLer directory and its contents, creating the user preferences if it doesn't exist, and checking if a new version of the program or data files are available.
Destroys the splash screen and displays the main program window.

section.para: The first time that you execute HamQSLer, the splash screen will look similar to this:

figure.title: Splash Screen First Time HamQSLer Started

section.para: There may be one or more additional messages, but as long as the Continue button is displayed you may click that to continue on to see what the main program window looks like.

If only a Terminate button is visible, a non-recoverable error has occurred and this must be corrected before you can go any further. If you cannot determine the cause or solution of the problem from the messages displayed on the splash screen, see the Program Initialization and the Splash Screen chapter.

section.title: HamQSLer Main Program Window
section.para: After you click the Continue button on the splash screen, the splash screen disappears, and the main program window, shown below, is displayed.

The first time that you start HamQSLer, only the QSOs function tab will be shown. After you have created one or more cards, and depending on certain user preferences, there may be an additional tab for each card the next time that you start the program.

The function tabs select the view that is displayed in the Work Area. The QSOs tab shows the loaded QSOs for which cards may be printed. The QSOs panel, shown in the image below, contains 6 QSOs that have been loaded from an ADIF file, the Sort Cards Panel, and the QSOs filters tabs. The Sort Cards Panel allows you to sort the cards by date and time, by callsign, or by a combination of QSL bureau and manager or callsign. There are four QSOs filters tab, each of which contain filters for selecting QSOs. The four filters are:

The image below shows the card design panel and card properties panel. The image shows the design panel immediately after a new card has been created. Note the tab label of "New Card" and the window title contains this text as well. This label and window title change to the name of the card file when the card is saved. The X button on the tab can be used to close the tab.

With no card item (text, background or other image, or the QSOs Box) selected, the properties panel contains default print properties for the card. The image above shows this. We will discuss printing and this panel later in this tutorial. When a card item is selected, the properties panel changes to show the properties for that card item.

section.title: Setting a Few User Preferences
section.para: Now that you are familiar with the main program window, we will start to create a sample QSL card. But before we begin with the actual design of the card, we must first set a few user preferences.
Select the User Preferences... menu item from the Edit dropdown menu. This will display the User Preferences dialog shown in the image below.

section.title: Select the Default Text Font
section.para: Click on the triangle to the left of "TextItems", or double-click on the "TextItems" text to open the expander. Now click on "Default Text Font" to display the Default Text Font panel. See the image below.

The dropdown list contains a list of every font that is registered on your computer. Select the font that you want as the default font for all text items. Don't worry, the font can be set individually for each text item when you design your card. Sample text in the selected font face is shown in the text block below the dropdown.
You can click on the Apply button to save this change, or wait until you have made additional changes before applying them.

section.title: Set Your Default Callsign
section.para: Click on "Callsign Text" under the TextItems expander to display the Callsign Text item panel. There is a text editing field that contains the text "MyCall". Change "MyCall" to the callsign that you most often use. Do not click the Macros button; we will discuss this later when we look at the salutation.
The image below shows what you should see at this point, replacing VA3HJ with your callsign.
Either click on the Apply button to save this change, or wait until more changes have been made.

section.title: Set Your Name and QTH
section.para: Click on "Name and QTH Text" under the Text Items expander to display the Name and QTH item panel. The panel contains a text editing field containing the text "MyQth". Change this text to your name and mailing address, using the Return key at the end of all except the last line. Again, do not click the Macros button.
The image below shows what you would see at this point if you had entered my name and address.

tip.para: See Appendix C if you want to enter characters that are not available on your keyboard.

section.title: Set Salutation
section.para: Click on the "Salutation Text" item under the TextItems expander to display the Salutation panel. This panel contains only the Macros button. Click on this button to open the Text and Macros dialog. The dialog should look like this:

The first Static Text groupbox contains an edit box with the text "Thanks for the QSO" in it. The Static Text groupbox at the bottom of the dialog similarly contains an edit box with the text ". 73," in it. The groupbox in the middle, labeled "Count Macro", contains fields for editing the content of a CountMacro. Macros are beyond the scope of this tutorial; the CountMacro is simply mentioned here because we will discuss it later while we design a sample card. Click the Close button to close the dialog.
Macros are discussed in the Macros chapter.

section.title: Select the Default QSOs Box Font
section.para: Open the QSOs Box expander and click on the "Default QSOs Box Font" text to open the Default QSOs Box Font panel. This panel is similar to the Default Text Font panel. Select the font to display QSO information in; this font may be the same or different than the default text font.
All user preferences are discussed in the Setting User Preferences chapter.
Click on the OK button to save the changes and to close the dialog.
Now that we have set a number of user preferences, it is time to design your first card.

section.title: Creating a Default Card
section.para:
To create a card, click on the Cards dropdown menu. Click on New, and then Bureau Card. Note that you can also just type
Ctrl N .
The image below shows the main window when you have performed this action. Note that the properties panel contains Default Printer Properties and Default Print Properties.

section.title: Selecting and Deselecting Card Items
section.para:
Move the mouse cursor over the card and the various text items and QSOs Box. Each item in turn is surrounded by an orange dashed rectangle. This indicates the card item that can be selected. With the mouse cursor over the card and not one of the text items or Qsos Box, click the
right mouse button
to display the card context menu.

The image above shows the context menu that is displayed. Click on the Select Highlighted Item menu item. The orange dashed rectangle changes to a blue dashed rectangle to indicate that the card (actually the Background Image) item is selected, and the properties panel changes to contain the properties associated with the Background Image.

Now click the
right mouse button
with the mouse cursor anywhere within the card design panel, even outside the card to redisplay the Select Context Menu. Click on the Deselect Selected Item menu item to deselect the selected card item.

Card items may also be selected and deselected using the Select dropdown menu. The menu contains a menu item for each card item on the card; for any Image items that have been added for which a filename has been specified, there is a menu item that contains the name of the image file, and for Image items for which a filename has not been specified, the menu items are labeled "Image". The menu items for text items are labeled with the first ten characters of the text. There is also a menu item with the label "Qsos Box" to allow selection of the Qsos Box.
The final menu item in the Select dropdown menu, labeled "None" is used to deselect the selected card item.

The image below shows the Select dropdown menu for the card in its current state. The labels for the callsign and name and QTH menu items will match the first ten letters of the callsign and name and QTH field that you set in the user preferences earlier.

section.title: Setting the Background Image
section.para: Select the background using either the Select context menu or the Select dropdown menu. The card will be surrounded by a blue dashed line indicating that it is selected, and the properties panel will contain the background image properties panel, shown in the image below.
Click on the button labeled "..." to open the file open dialog, shown below.

The dialog opens in the hamqsler directory in your documents directory (My Documents). The actual directory is determined by a user preferences setting; see the User Preferences chapter for more information.
Navigate to the Samples directory and select the sample.jpg file. The program's main window will now look like this:

figure.title: Main Window With Background Image Added to Card

section.para: Note the selection rectangle has now extended above and below the top and bottom of the card. The rectangle now outlines the edges of the background image, which does not have the same aspect ratio as the card. Also, in the background image properties panel, the location of the image file is shown below the "..." button.

Move the mouse cursor over the background image. The cursor changes to
unless you are using a custom set of mouse cursors. This is the move cursor. Press and hold the left mouse button and drag the mouse around the screen to move background image.

To change the size of the image, release the mouse button, then move the mouse cursor to one of the four corners of the image. The cursor will change to either
or
to indicate that you are over the corner of the image. Press and hold the left mouse button, then drag the cursor away from the centre of the image to increase the size of the image, and drag the cursor towards the centre of the image to decrease the size of the image.
It is difficult to return the image to its original size and position. A simpler way to do this is to reload the image. Do so now.

section.title: Setting Text Items
section.para: Deselect the background image using either the context menu or Select dropdown menu. Select the callsign text item. The text item properties panel, shown below, will now be displayed in the properties panel.
There are a number of properties related to text items; we will look at each of them in turn.

The font dropdown box contains all of the fonts registered with your operating system. The font that is currently selected is the font that you selected in the user preferences earlier in this tutorial. Select a different font. The callsign on the card is now displayed in that font. Notice that only this text changed font, not the other text items.

The text may be displayed in Bold or Normal weight by checking or unchecking the Bold checkbutton. Italic or Normal style may be selected by checking and unchecking the Italic checkbutton. Try this. For the callsign text, the default is normal style and Bold.

The size dropdown box contains a number of predefined font sizes (in points). 48 is the default value for callsigns. You can select any of the sizes directly from the list, or edit the size box to enter any size that you want. Try entering a character other than a number, ".", or ",". Note the beep emitted by your computer to indicate that you entered an invalid character. Now select the font size that you want.
The color button (the button with the black rectangle) shows the color that the text is displayed in. Click on this button to open the color picker dialog, shown below.

The color picker lets you set a color in a number of different ways. For example, you can select one of the basic or custom colors shown in swatches on the left side of the dialog, or you can select a custom color by clicking in the rainbow on the right side of the dialog and then adjusting the slider to the right of the rainbow to adjust the luminance value. Alternatively you may enter hue, saturation and luminance values or red, green and blue values in the entry boxes below the rainbow. To save as a custom color for later use in the program, click on the "Add to Custom Colors" button.

For this tutorial, a bright orange works best. Set red to 255, green to 128, and blue to 0. Save this as a custom color because we will be using it again, then click the OK button. This closes the color picker dialog. The button in the text item properties panel now displays an orange rectangle, and the callsign text on the card is displayed in orange.

The group box labeled Text holds an edit box containing the text of the callsign. Make some changes to the text and note that the changes are immediately reflected on the card. Reset the text to your callsign.
Ignore the "Macros" button for now.

The Checkboxes group box contains four controls, a checkbutton for adding a checkbox in front of the text, a checkbutton for adding a checkbox after the text, a slider for adjusting the thickness of the lines making up the checkboxes, and a slider to set the size of the checkboxes as a percentage of the height of the text. Adjust each of these controls to see the effect they have. The line thickness and check box ratio sliders only have an effect when at least one of the checkbuttons is checked. Note that the checkboxes are displayed in the same color as the text. Uncheck both checkbuttons.

Move the mouse cursor over the callsign text on the card. The mouse cursor will change to the move cursor. Press and hold the left mouse button, and drag the text to be near the top left corner of the card, then release the mouse button.

Deselect the callsign text and select the text with your name and QTH. Change the color of the text to the same orange color as the callsign. Adjust the position of the text so that the top of the top line of the text is in line with the top of the callsign text. Position the text so that it is to the right of the callsign. Deselect the text item.

tip.para: See Appendix C if you want to enter characters that are not available on your keyboard.

section.para: Now look at the salutation text on the card. Note the text is "Thanks for the QSO$. 73, ". The "$" character is a placeholder for a Count Macro. We will look at this macro in a moment.
Select the salutation text item. In the text item properties panel, note that Text group box contains only a Macros button. Click on this button to open the Text and Macros dialog.

The Text and Macros dialog will contain three main group boxes: the groupbox at the top of the dialog, labelled "Static Text", contains a text edit box with the text "Thanks for the QSO", The second main group box, labelled "Count Macro" will be discussed in a moment. The third main group box located at the bottom of the dialog is labelled "Static Text" and contains a text edit box with the text ". 73," in it. The dialog will look like the image below.

The Count Macro group box contains controls for the contents of a Count Macro. A Count Macro displays text based on the number of QSOs rows that are printed in the QSOs Box for cards with no QSOs, and the number of QSOs printed for cards with QSOs. This count macro is set up to print "s" when the QSOs count is greater than one, print nothing when the QSOs count is 1, and to display "$" on the card in design mode. Each of these values, and the condition may be modified. See the Macros chapter for more information. We will not make any changes to the count macro or its text in this tutorial, so click the Close button to close the dialog.
Change the color of the text to the same orange color as the other text items, and make any adjustments to the position of the text that you would like. Deselect the salutation text item.
Your card should now look like this:

section.title: Setting Qsos Box Properties
section.para: Deselect any selected card item, then select the Qsos Box. The Qsos Box properties panel will be displayed in the properties panel. See the image below for a view of the Qsos Box properties panel. The panel contains many properties, and does not fit fully in the HamQSLer window. The scrollbar to the right of the panel may be used to scroll down to the remaining properties, or you may increase the height of the program's window to show all of the properties.

The text that is displayed in the Qsos Box (e.g. the confirming text (in the top line of the box, the text for each column header, and the text that is displayed in the QSL column, not yet shown on the card) is determined by user preferences and is fixed when the card is first created. See the User Preferences chapter for details on setting these values.

section.title: Setting QSOs and Fields Properties
section.para: Let's look at each property. The Show Manager checkbox when checked adds the text "via ZZZZZZ" to the confirmation line in design mode, and will replace "ZZZZZZ" with the other station's QSL manager if one exists and is included in the Manager column of the QSOs printed on the card. We will look at this later when we select the QSOs to be printed. If no manager exists, the text, including "via" is not printed. Check this checkbox as we will be using it later.

Below the Show Manager checkbox are two radio buttons, one labeled "Show Band Column" and the other labeled "Show Freq Column". When you create a card, the "Show Band Column" radio button is selected by default. These two radio buttons determine whether the Qsos Box displays a band column or a frequency column. Click the "Show Freq Column" button. Note that the Band column header has changed to "MHz" and that the size of the various columns have adjusted themselves.

What happens if you select the Band radio button but your logging program only logs frequency? When the ADIF file containing the QSOs is loaded, or when you manually input QSOs, a band field will be generated for each QSO, with the band corresponding to the band containing the logged frequency.

And what happens if you select the Frequency radio button but the QSO only has a band field and not a frequency field? When each card is printed, a default frequency for that band is substituted. The default frequency for each band may be set in the user preferences.
Make sure that the "Show Band Column" radio button is selected.

The QSL Pse/Tnx checkbox controls the visibility of the QSL column in the Qsos Box. When a card is first created, this checkbox is checked. Uncheck the checkbox; note that the column labeled "QSL" at the left of the Qsos Box has been removed, and the other columns have been resized. The values printed in this column depend on the value of the QSL_RCVD ADIF field for each QSO. If the field contains "Y" indicating that a QSL card has been received confirming this QSO, then the text "Tnx" is printed in the column for that QSO. If the column contains any other value, the text "Pse" is printed in the column. "Tnx" and "Pse" are default values; they may be changed in user preferences.
Make sure that the checkbox is checked before continuing with this tutorial.
The Date Format dropdown box contains three values:

The value selected determines both the text that is displayed in the date column header, and the format of the date printed for each QSO. Change to a different value to see the effect on the Qsos Box. Finally, set this value to YYYY-MM-DD for this tutorial.

The Max Qsos control specifies the maximum number of QSOs that may be printed on the card. The control is a dropdown box; you may select any value between 1 and 15. Try multiple values to see how the Qsos Box changes.
The default value when you create a new card is 4. There is no way to change this default.
Finally, set this value to 2.

section.title: Setting Line and Text Properties
section.para: There are three color buttons. Each button opens the color picker dialog to allow you to select a color. The three colors control the color of the lines and text in the Qsos Box, the color of the callsign in the confirming text, and the color of the manager in the confirming text. Set the line and text color to orange (red=255, green=128, blue=0), and set the manager color to green (red=0, green=255, blue=0).

The Font Size dropdown box contains values between 5.0 and 9.0. This sets the size of the font in the QSOs Box. Try different values. For the 2 QSOs that we have set as the maximum, a value of 9.0 points is good. Smaller values will be needed when you select a large Max QSOs value; otherwise the box would not fit on the card.

The Font dropdown box allows you to select the font that the text in the Qsos Box is displayed and printed in. The initial font selected in the dropdown box is the font that you specified as the default Qsos Box font in the User Preferences earlier. Select a few different fonts and notice how the height of the Qsos Box changes. The actual height of a line of text in each font will be different, even though the font size has not changed.
Set the font to a value that looks good to you.

section.title: Setting Qsos Box Background Properties
section.para: These properties control the color and the opacity (opposite of transparency) of the background of the Qsos Box.

Click on the Color button to display the color picker dialog. This dialog may be used to change the color of the background of the Qsos Box. Note that the background color of the QSOs Box is now your selected color.
The opacity slider adjusts the opacity of the background. Adjust the slider to select values between 0 and 100% to see the effect on the Qsos Box.
When you have finished playing, set the color to black (red=0, green=0, blue=0), and set the opacity to 30%. Note that a considerable amount of the detail in the background image shows through.

section.title: Adjusting the Position of the Qsos Box
section.para:
Move the mouse cursor over the Qsos Box. The cursor will change to
. Press the left mouse button and drag the Qsos Box. When you are done, release the mouse button. For this card, positioning the Qsos Box anywhere that is not over a text item will work.

Move the mouse cursor over the left or right edge of the QSOs Box. The cursor will change to
. This indicates that you can move that edge of the QSOs Box either left or right to change the width of the box. As you shrink the width of the QSOs Box, it will reach its minimum width based on the columns and font size selected, and will not shrink any more. The minimum width is determined by the width required to print the contents of all columns without the contents overlapping to other columns.
Resize the QSOs Box to approximately the width it was before. Deselect the Qsos Box. Your card should look similar to the image below:

section.title: Saving the Card
section.para: Select the Save Card As... menu item from the Cards dropdown menu. This opens the File Save dialog, shown in the image below:

Note that the dialog opens in the hamqsler directory. Select the Samples directory; enter the file name sample in the Name edit box near the top of the dialog, and click the Save button. The card will be saved with the name sample.xq1.
The text on the tab in the main window will change from "New Card*" to "sample.xq1".
In the future, this card may be opened using the Open Card... menu item in the Cards dropdown menu.
We are now done designing the card, so let's load an ADIF file containing some QSOs to select for printing.

section.title: Selecting QSOs to Print on the Card
section.para: Click on the QSOs tab. Select Import QSOs... from the QSOs dropdown menu. This opens the File Open dialog in the hamqsler directory. Select the Samples directory, and open the file sample.adi. The program main window should look like this:

section.title: Selecting QSOs Sort Order
section.para: The QSOs properties panel is shown below.

As noted here, when an ADIF file is first imported, the QSOs are sorted by date and time. QSOs may also be sorted by manager and callsign, and by bureau followed by manager and callsign. Select each of the sort order radio buttons and note how the order of the QSOs changes in the QSOs panel.

With the Bureau radio button set, note that all QSOs with the Send Via column set to "Bureau" are sorted to the top of the QSOs panel, followed by QSOs whose Send Via is set to Direct. The values in the Send Via column are set according to the values of the QSL_SENT_VIA field in ADIF records as follows:
Even though some QSOs may have a value of Electronic or Manager in the Send Via column, it is still possible to include these QSOs on cards that you print.
Leave the Bureau radio button selected.

section.title: Selecting QSOs by Band
section.para: Note that the checkboxes in the Include column for all QSOs are checked to indicate that all QSOs will be printed on cards.
In the QSOs properties panel, click on the Band tab. The expanded widget looks like this:
Uncheck the 40m checkbox. Note that the checkbox in the Include column of the third QSO is now unchecked; this is the only QSO that took place on the 40m band.
Leave this unchecked.

section.title: Selecting QSOs by Mode
section.para: Click on the Mode tab; it looks like the image below. Note that the list contains submode values from the QSOs, and only contains a mode value if the QSO does not have a submode field.
Uncheck the CW checkbox. All QSOs in the CW mode are deselected. Reselect the CW mode checkbox. Again all QSOs except the QSO on 40m are selected.
Leave all modes checked.

section.title: Selecting QSOs by Date and Time
section.para: Click on the Date/Time tab. The tab contents look like this:

The start date and time fields contain the date and time of the earliest QSO in the QSOs panel. The end date and time correspond to the date and time of the latest QSO. Change the start date to "20021201". Note that the QSOs whose start date occur before this date are now unchecked. Similarly, you could change the start time and the end date and time to uncheck other QSOs.
Now click the Reset button. The start and end dates are reset to the dates and times of the earliest and latest QSOs.

section.title: Selecting QSOs by QSL Statuses
section.para: The image below shows the content of the QSL Status tab. It contains three sections, one for Rcvd statuses, one for Sent statuses, and one for Sent Via statuses.
Select various statuses to see the QSOs that are selected and deselected. When you are finished, make sure that all checkboxes are checked.

section.title: Selecting Individual QSOs
section.para: You may select individual QSOs by checking and unchecking the checkboxes in the Include column. To do this, you must click on the checkbox itself. If you click anywhere else on the QSO, the QSO is selected. this is not what you want at this time.
It is also possible to check and uncheck all QSOs at once or multiple QSOs at a time. That is covered in the chapter titled Working With QSOs.
Before proceeding, make sure that only the third QSO is unchecked.

section.title: Default Printer and Print Options Properties
section.para: Click on the tab labeled "sample.xq1" to redisplay the card that you designed earlier.

With no card items selected, the card properties panel contains printer properties and print properties. The default values are the values that are set in User Preferences. Because we did not change these values earlier, the printer is set to the computer system's default printer. The paper size, quality, and paper source are set to the default values for this printer.

The print properties are also set to the defaults set in User Preferences. These values control how the cards are printed. If the "Print Inside Printer Margins" checkbox is checked and disabled, and the "Set Card Margins to Printer Margins" checkbox is unchecked and disabled, then the minimum printer margins for the selected printer has one or more margins that exceeds ¼ inch or 6.35 mm. Printer margins and the reasons for forcing printing inside the printer margins are discussed in the Outputting Cards chapter
There are two checkboxes that affect the card in display mode as well as print mode:

listitem.para: "Print Card Outlines" checkbox determines whether a black line is drawn around the outside of the card. This helps to determine where the card edges are when you cut the cards out of the cardstock. Check this box; note that a line is drawn around the card in the Card Design Panel.

"Set Card Margins to Printer Margins" checkbox determines whether card contents are printed with a margin inside the card edges or card contents are printed to the edges of each card. If you select a card layout on your cardstock such that one or more cards abut the edges of the cardstock, then the edges of those cards abutting the cardstock edges will have a margin on them when printed. This occurs because printers do not normally print to the edges of paper. In order to look better, checking the Set Card Margins to Printer Margins checkbox will provide a margin around all edges of every card equal to the widest minimum margin for your printer. Check this checkbox now if the checkbox is not disabled. Notice that there is now a margin inside the edges of the card in the Card Design Panel.

section.para: The other two checkboxes only affect the card when printed:

listitem.para: "Print Inside Card Margins" checkbox determines whether you can place cards up to the edges of your cardstock. When this checkbox is checked, the cards are placed to ensure that their edges are inside the printer's page margins; when not checked, cards may be placed at the edges of the cardstock.

"Fill Last Page With Blank Cards" checkbox determines if the last sheet of cardstock will be filled with cards with no QSO information printed in the QSOs Box. In many cases, the number of cards being printed is not evenly divisible by the number of cards that are printed on each page. This wastes cardstock. In order to maximize the use of the cardstock, you can print blank cards on the last page in order to fill the cardstock. You may use these cards at a later time to write QSO information on them rather than print new cards.

section.title: Printing Cards
section.para: Select the Print Cards... menu item from the Cards dropdown menu. This opens the Print dialog shown below.
As you can see, the printer properties and print properties are displayed again. The settings in this dialog match the settings for the card. This is your last chance to make changes before printing.
Check the "Print Card Outlines" and "Fill Last Page With Blank Cards" checkboxes.

The third group box on the dialog is the cards layout group box. This box shows various card layouts on the cardstock. The white rectangles surrounded by blue lines represent the cards, with the cardstock shown in pink. If you change paper size and check or uncheck the "Print Inside Printer Margins" checkbox, the cards layouts will change. In some cases these changes are subtle and in other cases the number of cards that can be printed per page changes.

For this tutorial, make sure that the paper size is set to either Letter or A4 size. The "Print Card Outlines" and "Fill Last Page With Blank Cards" checkboxes should also be checked. Click on the radio button at the right of the first row of card layouts. Now click on the Preview button at the bottom of the dialog. This will create a print preview of the cards as shown in the image below.
There is a toolbar at the top of the dialog shown in the image below.
The buttons on this toolbar from left to right are as follows:
There is a spin box at the top right of the dialog that allows you to scroll through the various pages.
Press the Display two pages button so that the dialog looks like the image above.

On the first page, the first card contains the two QSOs with VA3JNO, with VA3HJ as the manager. The second card contains a single QSO with VA3JNO, and the third card contains a single QSO with 5C5CW. If the maximum number of QSOs on a card had been set to 1, only a single QSO would have been printed on each card.

Note that on the cards with one QSO, the confirming text in the QSOs Box is "Confirming 2-Way QSO with ...", and the salutation text is "Thanks for the QSO. 73,". On the card with two QSOs the texts are "Confirming 2-Way QSOs with..." and "Thanks for the QSOs. 73,". The inclusion and exclusion of the "s" on "QSO" is controlled by a Count Macro. See the Macros chapter for more information.

Now view the second page of cards. The first card is for the QSO with CG3JNO, and the last two cards contain a QSOs Box with two empty lines. These cards are printed because you checked the "Fill Last Page With Blank Cards" checkbox.
Every card is surrounded by a black line on all sides because you checked the "Print Card Outlines" checkbox.

You will probably notice that the cards are not centered on the cardstock even though we selected the card layout that should have centered the cards. In fact, the cards are shifted left and up by the size of the left and top margins for your printer. Don't worry about this. If you were to click the print button, the cards would be printed in the middle of the cardstock; the offset in Print Preview is caused by the print processing in .Net. More information about printing is included in the Outputting Cards chapter.
Close the print preview dialog. Go back and try the various print options settings combinations to see the effect that each setting has.

section.title: Concluding the Tutorial
section.para: You have now concluded this tutorial, but you have only scratched the surface of the capabilities ofHamQSLer. Be sure to read the remaining chapters in this user manual as they contain more information on every aspect of the program and also contain many helpful hints and suggestions to get the most out of HamQSLer.
